body:
Prefer fasted is the worst since its equivalent to allowing infinite
workspace.  We were using it before. I changed to limit workspace a while
back.
On Feb 4, 2016 12:19 PM, "Mu Li" notifications@github.com wrote:

> can you have a try with the PREFER_FASTEST flag? i tested last night but
> it decreases the performance, i guess it's probably due to incorrect
> workspace size.
> 
> does 'auto' work?
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/1409#issuecomment-180029594.

Well that's dumb of cudnn. It would be cool to do some sort of graph optimization like (http://benanne.github.io/2014/12/09/theano-metaopt.html) to auto pick. I will run the PREFER_FASTEST on my test when my gpu's are free again.

With PREFER_FASTEST enabled for everything in the convolution my speeds are:
16 examples a second. So exactly as @piiswrong suggested.

I think the lua_state are completely separate and thus would have a separate garbage collector. (http://stackoverflow.com/questions/17653530/is-it-possible-to-share-a-table-between-multiple-lua-state-in-a-single-threaded)

The crash does appear to happen for both criterion and modules but its hard to 100% confirm. My test case is as follows:

``` python
import mxnet as mx


def crash_combo_criterion():
    data = mx.sym.Variable(name="data")
    label = mx.sym.Variable(name="softmax_label")

    fc1 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=data, num_hidden=10, name='fc1')
    logsoftmax = mx.symbol.TorchModule(data_0=fc1, lua_string='nn.LogSoftMax()', num_data=1, num_params=0, num_outputs=1, name='logsoftmax')
    # Torch's label starts from 1
    softmax = mx.symbol.TorchCriterion(data=logsoftmax, label=label+1, lua_string='nn.ClassNLLCriterion()', name='softmax')
    mse = mx.symbol.TorchCriterion(data=data, label=data+1, lua_string='nn.MSECriterion()', name="mse", label_shape=(10,))
    cost = softmax + mse*10

    executor = cost.simple_bind(data=(12, 10), softmax_label=(12,), ctx=mx.gpu(3))

    for i in range(1000):
        executor.forward()
        executor.backward()
        executor.outputs[0].asnumpy()

def crash_modules():
    data = mx.sym.Variable(name="data")

    fc1 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=data, num_hidden=10, name='fc1')
    logsoftmax = mx.symbol.TorchModule(data_0=fc1, lua_string='nn.LogSoftMax()', num_data=1, num_params=0, num_outputs=1, name='logsoftmax')
    logsoftmax2 = mx.symbol.TorchModule(data_0=fc1, lua_string='nn.LogSoftMax()', num_data=1, num_params=0, num_outputs=1, name='logsoftmax')

    cost = logsoftmax + logsoftmax2

    executor = cost.simple_bind(data=(12, 10), ctx=mx.gpu(3))
    out = mx.nd.zeros((12, 10), ctx=mx.gpu(3))

    for i in range(1000):
        executor.forward()
        executor.backward([out])
        executor.outputs[0].asnumpy()

crash_combo_criterion()
#crash_modules()
```

I was unable to get these to crash however without a modification to the lua threads library.
The modification is to add a `collectgarbage("collect")` call just before the return in `serialize.load` and `serialize.save`. It is my understanding is telling lua to collect garbage should never release used instances and should never cause a crash.

The error message is slightly different than before

Here is a temporary work around: Since crash happens in serialization/deserialzation, we can remove the need for them by making a lua_state per operator, instead of per thread. 
The down side of this is every operator will have to load a copy of torch. But hopefully torch lib doesn't take up that much memory.
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/1074.patch or you can use cherry-pick commits you want.
The score map has shape "batchsize x 21 x heigh x width". This is what I want to upsample.
Yeah, the converter is a little out of date. Are you interested in proposing a PR on this? It should be easy.
2&3 will work. 1 doesn't
bilinear upsampling internally calls deconvolutional layer. You need larger workspace for deconvolutional layer. Currently there is no interface for  that. You need to change the c++ code.

Did you run the tests to see the current number? The doc is probably out dated since it was likely produced with cudnn v3.
@tqchen @jermainewang

NDArrayHandle is defined as void\* so the first one is correct.
The second one is indeed a mistake. Thanks for reporting the error.
@fengjunlv Thanks for reporting the issue. Could you do a bisect "https://git-scm.com/docs/git-bisect" and pin point the change that caused this?

could due to my recent change to dmlc-core to increase the ingestion buffer size. I know reverted dmlc-core back to the same setting as in this commit https://github.com/dmlc/dmlc-core/commit/2d1db230e5fb0bf32bfed4e425b6fe20d05aa1c3 

@piiswrong please send a PR to update dmlc-core and see if this issue is fixed
@piiswrong Unfortunately, I am not sure which version it is that used to be working. It was pulled and compiled quite a few days ago. Hopefully what tqchen has found out will fix the issue.
@tqchen doesn't seem to fix it on my machine. Training still takes 16G ram
@piiswrong I see, can you look a bit into what happened?
I tried, but couldn't find a working version to start bisecting. Memory consumption starts when ImageRecordIter is created, before training starts. So you shouldn't need gpu to debug this.
Out of curiosity - why didn't this get caught by a gradient check?
Because we don't have GPU test server for a while.
@tqchen Hi,thx for the suggestion. But the way you propose cannot significantly reduce the memory usage.
this is a old issuse
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/826
try inception

I suggest to modify the example codes to make new users start easily. The code modification should be straightforward, e.g. provide get_initializer() for each example model and pass it as an argument to train_model.fit
the first one is inputs[i]?  I think it's outputs[i]
ok. I see what you mean.
@javelinjs  good idea
@realbns2008 Could you make a PR for this issue?

sgd need to store momentum, which basically double the memory needed by parameters. python sgd also need intermediate variables. using ccsgd might solve the problem as it doesn't need intermediate variable, but it still need to store momentum.

Same problem is here. I use prefetch_buffer = 1 but still my data fills all the way of 30GB memory then raises out of memory error.

I also have one old version of mxnet and it works with no problem. It seems something with a new update disrupt the code.

that's interesting, probably due to cudnn v3/v4 or the fft-based convolution. we did measurement a month ago, these platforms, torch/caffe/mxnet, are comparable on cnns. we need to find out what happens there.
Or weechat, that will be real time.

Same issue here with mxnet and python. I installed the latest windows build 20160202 and while training a network the accuracy wasn't increasing. The computation was taking place on the gpu because I checked it with gpu-z.... 
Did the simple arithmetic tests on gpu  mentioned by @piiswrong and it gave me zeroes.

So I switched to the 20151228 build and now it works ok.

So definately the bug from 20160106 still exists in 20160202. Hope it helps.....
thanks @pppoe It has been added to the example

Setup a google group maillist here https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/mxnet

Mainly aim to use this as maillist purposes for discussions. The options such as issue still available

did a benchmark on mnist with lenet (batch size = 256) and openblas

|  | lenet (img/s) | cpubenchmark.net |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 2 x e5-2630 v3 | 676 | 12877 |
| 2 x e5-2670 | 604 | 12514 |
| e5-1620 v3 | 540 | 9658 |
| i7-4790 | 546 | 10019 |
| i5-3470 | 476 | 6567 |

there is a large system overhead, probably due to most threads are idle. in the most two expensive mshadow functions, there are a large mount of `cmp`, `mov`, and `imul`. hope it helps
Just submitted a PR that does just this. I gave up trying to track down the bad references. I think its something to do with the output variable on the nn.Module but I am not sure.

Thanks! I made a few comments.
Have you confirmed if this solves your random segfault problem?

The newest version seems does not require so much memory. But after updating to the newest version. I got a problem 

> src/io/iter_image_recordio.cc:56: Check failed: p != end Bad ImageList format.

Am I missing something in the multi-label for a Single Image? Thanks.
but i remember most people voted disqus on #1020
The original proposal actually meant  https://www.discourse.org/ . Anyway, we can go with either option but stick to one as long as it is good for the user

Your combined data iter has 2 labels, so it doesn't match the output of your network. You can write a custom iterator to throw away the second one. Or you can modify prefetching iter to add the feature of throwing away some input.
got it. we can host it at dmlc.ml, but needs to do some maitainings
Sorry, it is not PASCAL. It is another dataset. I guess I have to transform the label into continuous index right? like 0-20 and 255. Then it would make sense.

Hi @jimxinbo 
Would you please share your multi-label softmax layer and the evaluation metric? Thanks!
Let us use google group for now then, since it does not require hosting effort

I would be willing/interested to help out with maintaining a discourse installation. It seems the easiest thing is to install it via docker. https://github.com/discourse/discourse/blob/master/docs/INSTALL.md
I faced similar problem, 'make clean_all' worked! Thanks a lot!

@vchuravy There were seg-faults in the Julia testing. This is due to an upstream change in the C-API functions. I have updated the Julia code to adapt this change. I will make a new release of the Julia package soon.

You can bind multiple executors that share memory if you are never using them in parallel. Look into Executor.reshape for example. If your use case is applying the same network with different input shapes, you can directly use reshape(). Otherwise, you need to bind shared mem executors by yourself.
@piiswrong updated with changes. Let me know if there is anything else.

I noticed this a well. For me on os x. But the issue is not that len(X) is 0, its that you are taking logs of zeros. The probabilities assigned by the output layer have lots of zeros in them so np.log(0) gives an error.
Thanks..looks like there is a marked improvement in performance..get a factor of two improvement. still verifying
Looks like the same issue as https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/1322
@vchuravy up now, http://forum.dmlc.ml/c/mxnet

My case is not using the same network with different input shapes but dealing with different networks. I just want to know, if I bind another network, how I could clear the previous one, or it gets cleared automatically?
@vchuravy discourse is surprisingly fancy, love it a lot:)

I mean like if first I set executor = net1.bind(...) and then I set executor = net2.bind(...), since it is the same variable, does it mean the first executor object will get released and cleared and the second created will be assigned to it. So I dont clear it manually, is that so? Just want to make sure. Thanks
It depends on the behavior of python's garbage collector. memory will be freed up when python executor object destructs. You can refer to python's document for that.

Are you trying to train networks on a single machine with multiple gpu or a cluster of multiple machines?
Single machine multiple gpu is easily done with FeedForward(ctx=[mx.gpu(0), mx.gpu(1) ... ]).
Multi machine distributed training can be done with this script: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/tools/launch.py

Trying on a machine with multiple-GPUs. Can you please explain more how and where I can use FeedForward? I am new to this and using this command to run:
$python example/image-classification/alexnet.py ---gpus all
The alexnet.py is from [here](https://github.com/soumith/convnet-benchmarks/blob/master/mxnet/alexnet.py)

use example/image-classification/train_imagenet.py --gpus=0,1,2,...
It's explained in the doc. the evn variables should be left to default unless you know what you are doing.

Nice! Just signed up.

Hi, train_imagenet is failing :(

I think it is pretty necessary to bind different symbols dynamically. Because of the limited gpu memory, we can not run several networks in parallel, so binding them dynamically and assigning corresponding parameters can be necessary. So how could I do this without being out of memory? To be specific, how could I clear the memory up and set up a new network afterwards? @piiswrong

you can try delete executor.

I think I found a solution, just make the executor a local variable in a function. When the function returns, it gets released. Here I want to know more about the difference between bind and simple_bind. Since simple_bind only needs the shape of input, so unlike bind, which requires grad_arrays, does simple_bind need more time to allocate memory for grad_arrays? Is this just trivial time, or I have to consider? so if I simple_bind and create an executor for each batch. Do I have to worry about this time consumption? Thanks a lot @piiswrong

If you are frequently creating executors, I strongly recommend you use similar mechanisms like in  executor.reshape to create shared memory executors. You can also cache them to mitigate construction cost.
atlas should include a libcblas.so. Locate it and add its path to flags. If you can't find it, your atlas is probably not correctly installed.
yes
